subject: Selected Tests for the Evaluation and Management of Infertility
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

The following tests or procedures are considered investigational and not medically necessary for diagnosing or managing infertility:

  • Endometrial receptivity analysis;
  • Sperm-capacitation test;
  • Sperm deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) fragmentation test;
  • Sperm penetration assay; and
  • Uterine natural killer (uNK) cells test.

  • Sperm-capacitation test;

  • Sperm penetration assay; and
  • Uterine natural killer (uNK) cells test.

subject: Testing for Biochemical Markers for Alzheimer’s Disease
html_content:
Medically Necessary:

Measurement of long form amyloid beta (also referred to as Aβ, Aβ1-42, Beta-amyloid [1-42], and Abeta42) in the cerebrospinal fluid is considered medically necessary in individuals for whom treatment with amyloid beta targeting therapy (for example, lecanemab-irmb [Leqembi™]) is being considered.

Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Measurements of biochemical markers (including but not limited to tau protein, long form amyloid beta, neural thread protein) is considered investigational and not medically necessary as a diagnostic technique for individuals with symptoms suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease when the criteria above have not been met.

Measurements of biochemical markers as a screening technique in asymptomatic individuals with or without a family history of Alzheimer’s disease is considered investigational and not medically necessary.
content:
Medically Necessary:
Measurement of long form amyloid beta (also referred to as Aβ, Aβ1-42, Beta-amyloid [1-42], and Abeta42) in the cerebrospinal fluid is considered medically necessary in individuals for whom treatment with amyloid beta targeting therapy (for example, lecanemab-irmb [Leqembi<sup>™</sup>]) is being considered.
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:
Measurements of biochemical markers (including but not limited to tau protein, long form amyloid beta, neural thread protein) is considered investigational and not medically necessary as a diagnostic technique for individuals with symptoms suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease when the criteria above have not been met.
Measurements of biochemical markers as a screening technique in asymptomatic individuals with or without a family history of Alzheimer’s disease is considered investigational and not medically necessary.

criteria.medical_act: Measurements of biochemical markers as a diagnostic technique for individuals with symptoms suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease

subject: Immune Cell Function Assay
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

An immune cell function assay is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications including, but not limited to:

  • Management of solid organ transplant rejection in an individual undergoing immunosuppressive therapy;
  • Identification of risk for rejection prior to kidney or any other solid organ transplantation;
  • Management of autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation;
  • Management of immunodeficiency disorders including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) and immune mediated disorders including rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and multiple sclerosis;
  • Testing for urticaria;
  • Diagnosis and management of Lyme disease.
content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary: An immune cell function assay is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications including, but not limited to:
  • Management of solid organ transplant rejection in an individual undergoing immunosuppressive therapy;
  • Identification of risk for rejection prior to kidney or any other solid organ transplantation;
  • Management of autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation;
  • Management of immunodeficiency disorders including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) and immune mediated disorders including rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and multiple sclerosis;
  • Testing for urticaria;
  • Diagnosis and management of Lyme disease.

criteria.description: An immune cell function assay is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications including, but not limited to:

Identification of risk for rejection prior to kidney or any other solid organ transplantation
Management of autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation

Management of immunodeficiency disorders including human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) and immune mediated disorders including rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and multiple sclerosis
Diagnosis and management of Lyme disease

subject: Fecal Analysis in the Diagnosis of Intestinal Disorders
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Fecal analysis panels are considered investigational and not medically necessary as a diagnostic test for the evaluation of intestinal dysbiosis, irritable bowel syndrome, malabsorption or small intestinal overgrowth of bacteria.

Fecal analysis of the following components is considered investigational and not medically necessary as a diagnostic test for the evaluation of intestinal dysbiosis, irritable bowel syndrome, malabsorption or small intestinal overgrowth of bacteria:

  • Beta-glucuronidase;
  • Cholesterol;
  • Chymotrypsin;
  • Fecal secretory IgA;
  • Iso-butyrate, N-butyrate;
  • Iso-valerate and N-valerate;
  • Levels of Lactobacilli, bifidobacteria and E. coli and other “potential pathogens,” including Aeromona, Bacillus cereus, Campylobacter, Citrobacter, Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas, Salmonella, Shigella, S. aureus, Vibrio Identification and quantitation of fecal yeast (including C. albicans, C. tropicalis, Rhodotorula and Geotrichum);
  • Long chain fatty acids;
  • Meat and vegetable fibers;
  • pH;
  • Short chain fatty acid distribution (adequate amount and proportions of the different short chain fatty acids reflect the basic status of intestinal metabolism);
  • Total short chain fatty acids;
  • Triglycerides.
content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary: Fecal analysis panels are considered investigational and not medically necessary as a diagnostic test for the evaluation of intestinal dysbiosis, irritable bowel syndrome, malabsorption or small intestinal overgrowth of bacteria. Fecal analysis of the following components is considered investigational and not medically necessary as a diagnostic test for the evaluation of intestinal dysbiosis, irritable bowel syndrome, malabsorption or small intestinal overgrowth of bacteria:
  • Beta-glucuronidase;
  • Cholesterol;
  • Chymotrypsin;
  • Fecal secretory IgA;
  • Iso-butyrate, N-butyrate;
  • Iso-valerate and N-valerate;
  • Levels of Lactobacilli, bifidobacteria and E. coli and other “potential pathogens,” including Aeromona, Bacillus cereus, Campylobacter, Citrobacter, Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas, Salmonella, Shigella, S. aureus, Vibrio Identification and quantitation of fecal yeast (including C. albicans, C. tropicalis, Rhodotorula and Geotrichum);
  • Long chain fatty acids;
  • Meat and vegetable fibers;
  • pH;
  • Short chain fatty acid distribution (adequate amount and proportions of the different short chain fatty acids reflect the basic status of intestinal metabolism);
  • Total short chain fatty acids;
  • Triglycerides.

subject: In Vitro Chemosensitivity Assays and In Vitro Chemoresistance Assays
html_content:
Not Medically Necessary:

In vitro chemosensitivity assays, as a guide to selection of chemotherapeutic drugs for individuals with cancer, are considered not medically necessary for all indications.

In vitro chemoresistance assays including, but not limited to, extreme drug resistance assays are considered not medically necessary for all indications.

subject: Rupture of Membranes Testing in Pregnancy
html_content:
Not Medically Necessary:

Evaluation of cervicovaginal fluid for specific amniotic fluid protein(s), (for example, placental alpha microglobulin-1 [PAMG-1], placental protein 12 [PP12], alpha-fetoprotein), is considered not medically necessary for all indications, including detection of preterm rupture of membranes.

subject: Selected Blood, Serum and Cellular Allergy and Toxicity Tests
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

The following blood, serum and cellular allergy or toxicity tests are considered investigational and not medically necessary: 

  • Antigen leukocyte cellular antibody test (ALCAT); or
  • Basophil activation test (BAT); or
  • Cytotoxic test; or
  • HEMOCODE Food Tolerance System; or
  • IgG food sensitivity test; or
  • Immuno Blood Print test; or
  • Leukocyte histamine release test (LHRT); or
  • Mediator Release Test.

  • Basophil activation test (BAT); or

  • Leukocyte histamine release test (LHRT); or
  • Mediator Release Test.

subject: Advanced Lipoprotein Testing
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Advanced lipoprotein testing (testing beyond that of a basic lipid panel) is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications, including for cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk assessment and management. Advanced lipoprotein testing includes, but is not limited to:

  • Apolipoprotein A-I (apoAI);
  • Apolipoprotein B (apoB);
  • Apolipoprotein E (apoE);
  • Intermediate density lipoproteins (IDL);
  • Lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a)) enzyme immunoassay;
  • Lipoprotein-associated phospholipase A2 (Lp-PLA2);
  • Small density lipoproteins.
content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary: Advanced lipoprotein testing (testing beyond that of a basic lipid panel) is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications, including for cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk assessment and management. Advanced lipoprotein testing includes, but is not limited to:
  • Apolipoprotein A-I (apoAI);
  • Apolipoprotein B (apoB);
  • Apolipoprotein E (apoE);
  • Intermediate density lipoproteins (IDL);
  • Lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a)) enzyme immunoassay;
  • Lipoprotein-associated phospholipase A2 (Lp-PLA2);
  • Small density lipoproteins.
